text: you can't throw a stone without hitting
an LGBT person here in Washington DC it
is amazing and I think in part it's
become like that because we made it
it's Sunday in Washington DC and
Nellie's a gay friendly sports bar on
Ustream is hosting its weekly drag
brunch compared to the 50 states DC has
the highest concentration of gay people
in the country ten percent of adults in
the District of Columbia identify as
lesbian gay bisexual or transgender
according to a Gallup poll that's nearly
three times the national rate of three
and a half percent and twice as much as
the next closest state Hawaii and it's
no secret in the city which largely
embraces this segment of the population
this has become more of a neighborhood
bar where people commingle so it's very
busy with a lot of gay patrons but the
straights and neighborhood sports fans
all still come to I've been doing back
now for 16 years and when I first
started out I wouldn't even come out my
house in drag I wouldn't walk down the
street and drag when driving my car and
drag but now since gay is everywhere and
everybody it's more accepted in life now
I can go out my house I don't mind who
send me and while I'm in drag
however the nation's capital wasn't
always as accepting as it is now you
know when I was working downtown for
Associated Press I walked down K Street
it would have been about 90 to 93 and
held my boyfriend's hand on K Street
people to goggled at us you know it was
you just didn't see that kind of stuff
back then that kind of stuff was kept to
17th Street and you would stop holding
hands by the time he got to 15th Street
because you were starting to get into
neighborhoods we didn't want to get
beaten up even in the 90s when Bill
Clinton became the first president to
appoint openly gay people to his
administration and Barney Frank became
the first openly gay congressman
Washington was hardly a beacon of
Tolerance
I was interviewing to be Dick Gephardt
deputy chief of staff when he was the
House Majority Leader and I said you
know should I tell him I'm gay and and
Barney said no you're not you're not
interviewing to be his gay
chief-of-staff you're interviewing to be
his deputy chief of staff around the
same time robert Rabin then counseled to
Frank confronted homophobia in Congress
directly in a in a spewing of bipartisan
homophobia three members of the Oklahoma
delegation announced that they wouldn't
hire anyone who was gay here I was a
homosexual lawyer working on the hill
and I thought did this just happen these
people down the hall said they wouldn't
employ a homosexual maybe they don't
know that we're here so I and a group of
others formed a lesbian and gay
congressional staff association the fact
of outing ourselves and standing on the
steps of the Capitol and saying this is
who we are proved to be an important
step for a lot of people fred saiyans of
the Human Rights Campaign the nation's
largest LGBT equality lobbying group
which is based here in DC has a theory
that DC attracts young LGBT men and
women precisely because it's a place
where they can influence a national
discussion LGBT people in part by their
very own nature want to bring change to
American society they are deeply
invested in a progressive society one
that invites a great variety and
diversity of ideas of progress and so I
think that is in part what has driven
LGBT people to become concentrated here
in the nation's confidence once DC
turned the corner on gay rights and
allow gay marriage and it was like the
floodgates opened up so for a gay
african-american man in this city it is
a little bit easier then if I were to go
out west and go to San Francisco
so there's not gonna be as much of a
challenge for me to fit and culturally
so that I do believe that DC has
something special so as LGBT activists
worked in DC to make the country more
progressive that made DC more
progressive in turn attracting even more
LGBT men and women just socially people
talk to each other now socially people
accept each other and you know straight
people in general don't look at the LGBT
community as others they look at us as
neighbors and I didn't used to always
feel that way back at Nellie's on a
weeknight that's abundantly clear the
crowd here is diverse and focused on
trivia more than anything else
